div.head: To the Right Honourable Thomas Earl of Oory, Lord Deputy General of IRELAND, &c.
div.p:
THat the happy Indutry of former Ages (whereby we enjoy the benefit of o many ueful inventions) hath till left mater enough, for the contrivance and dicovery of ucceeding times, cannot be better made appear, than by calling to mind, thoe many worthy improvements, which almot all the more Liberal Arts, have received within the compas of this lat Century, epecially Phyick, wherein Anatomy alone (I may truly ay) hath been inriched, by a full third part at leat. And herein our own Countrymen, have been as uccesfully inquiitive, as any other their Contemporaries whatoever. No wonder then if in uch an Age, I, imitating their example, have thought fit, to give this account, of my leiure, to the world; but
that I offer it to the protection of o great a Patron; the reaons, perhaps, are not o manifet, as neceary. For as the Novelty of o unexpected a method, as I here propoe, will undoubtedly expoe it to the calumny of uch, who (rather than give themelves the trouble of examining the truth of it, being betimes perwaded, that they already know as much as is to be learnt) will oon condemn it, both of folly and innovation. So it eems of abolute neceity, that it bear with it the plendid name of ome great Peronage, the better to bepeak the judicious Readers charitable Cenure. Whoe name then could I more hopefully have prefixed, than that of your Lordhips, a peron o Noble by decent, o Eminent by your Great and Honorable Imployments, and o deervedly beloved and admired of all for that excellent compoure of Greatnes and Goodnes, o remarkable in your Lordhip; which attempt of mine, if it may receive a favourable Interpretation, I hall be obliged to continue

div.head: The Preface.
div.p:
I Hold it not unuitable to our deign in this Treatie (where I have o often occaion to make mention of it) that omething be aid by way of Preface, concerning the Air. Not that I intend to treat of it's firt or econd qualities, &c. Which I leave to the natural Philoophers conideration, much les of the Elatic power of it, in Pneumatick Engines; already o well performed by others, epecially by the Honorable Robert Boyl, in his mot accurate Treatie on that Subject: my purpoe here being only to preent my Reader, with ome few obervables concerning Air, the better to confirm and illutrate, what follows in the Treatie it elf: epecially in the Chapter of Fermentation. Firt therefore, that the Air is of ome very general ue, may well appear from its being o great in biquitarian, as it is. No place almot without it, no body (perhaps) but participating, more or les, of it; inomuch, that
even in metals themelves, the ound of them, it reckoned an affection of the Air included in them. And if the tranparency of Bodies be to be imputed to their porounes, or rather to the treightnes or rectitude of their pores, (as its almot generally agreed on by Modern Writers) it will follow, that there is a great proportion of Air in the hardet Gemmes. Which is yet more manifest in ofter tones, and becomes the caue of their moldring and cracking (after they are taken out of the Quarrey, and expoed to the weather) which ome ort of tones are very ubject to: For the imprioned Air, that while it was in the cold bowels of the Earth, lay very much condened or compreed, afterward ymbolizing with the Air of a thinner Medium, powerfully dilates its elf, and after ome time o weakens the continuity of parts, that at lat becoming too trong for it, the tone breaks into many pieces, which will ooner happen if the ame be thrown into the fire: the included Air, in uch cae, with much more violence dilating its elf, than in the former experiment. Plants eem to owe their very life and being to this included Air: for not having hearts, or other principal of motion in
them, (that we know of) for the ditributing of the Sap: the included Air eems to upply that defect, after this manner. In the day time, in hot weather, and generally as often as the Air of the Medium, is dilated or contracted: the Air included, in the body of every Vegetable, uffers after the ame manner, and has its dimenions and tone varied. Whereupon thee two coniderable effects follow, to wit, that upon the dilatation of the internal or included Air, the parts of the Vegetable are ditended (omewhat) according to their trinal dimenion, whereby the Plant grows bigger and taller. And again, upon the compreion of the internal Air, room is made for the water or ap, to rie up, through the pores of the Plant, exactly after the manner of the Weather-glas: where the compreion of the Air becomes the caue of the acent of the water. And thus according to thee periods of heat and cold, and the conequent rarity and denity of the included Air, and that of the Medium; every Plant makes, as it were, o many meals, or is o often refrehed, by the acending Sap, which acent is alo not a little promoted, by thoe gentle Vibrations from the winds, whereby the parts of Vegetables (and conequently
the included Air) are moderately compreed and dilated reciprocally; wherrupon the foreaid effects follow, even after the ame manner, as is aid of the Swing, and in the lat Chapter of this Treatie. The included Air erves likewie in Vegetables (as in all other bodies) for the maturing and fermenting the juices in them, in uch manner as is hereafter expreed. A farther confirmation whereof may be hence had, that the mot vegetous plants, and uch as we call Ever-Greens, abound most with Air in them: as appears when they are thrown into the fire, by the violent eruption of it. And there is, I think, no vegetable that has not one great pore or Pipe running from the root to the very top of it. Farther, in the Sea wrack, or Quercus Marina, 'tis obvious for every one to oberve a very particular and curious contrivance of Nature, for the nourihment of that plant, by the help of Air after this ort. The plant as always fatened to ome tone; and as it branches out, with jagged leafs, omewhat reembling thoe of the Oak: it hath everal little Bliters or Bladders on it (ome where of I have een as big as a mall Pullets Egg.) Now upon the coming in of the Tide, the water
riing this weed by means of the aid Bladders floats; and if the Stone be not too heavy Boys it up. (and hangs in the water like a Net that hath Corks and Leads to it) whereupon the Plant is coniderably tretched; and again, upon the ubiding of the water, receives its nourihment, as in the former intance of other vegetables, though perhaps not from the root, being fatened to a tone, but by the poroe urface of its body. And latly, that there is much Air dieminated through the bodies of Animals, is manifet from their food: herbs and water, both which participate of it in good quantity. A notable argument whereof in water, may be, that it doth upon uch eaie terms rie up in a vapour, and mingle its minute and inenible parts with the Air. For as the water grows warm, either by the heat of the Sun or fire, the mall parts of Air dilating, make hate to the top of the water, where they frame themelves, with ome of the water, into little bubbles; and are carried away by the motion of the Air or Medium, like thoe bubbles made by Children, with Soap and water. And this perhaps may be one reaon, why Rain water is better for plants, then other water, becaue it has more air in it; a tetimony
whereof the Scale may afford us. And this is manifest in wine even to ene: from which (if it be brisk and freh, and poured from on high, into a glas) you hall firt ee a great number of little bubbles, or floating parcels of Air rie up, with uch force, as to mount neer a foot, above the urface of the wine. But it is not enough for us to have proved great quantities of Air in all mixed bodies, unles it be at the ame time allowed us, that the Air be actually and formally there as in the Medium or open Air, uffering nothing ele but barely an imprionment, or confinement only, which is already ufficiently made out by the ues lately aigned it in vegetables, (unles they may be otherways more commodiouly explained) beides, that the poibility of converting one ubtance into another, was yet never o clearly taught, as to become intelligible, and has at this day but few Aerters of it.

In contemplation of all which particulars and that the Air alone, of all Simple Bodies is capable of dilatation and constriction (or call it rarity and denity) yet, not by any power to move it has of its elf, but as it is moved more or les, by the preence or abence,
the neernes or remotenes of the Sun (the heart and Center of this worldly Sytem in which we live) I thought it a matter worth my pains (though perhaps exceeding my abilities) to aay whether all fermentation, were not reducible to this imple motion of the Air, and did not depend on it, as on a general and more univeral caue; which if I fail not in, it will be no very difficult matter, to reduce all other motions in the world, to that of fermentation, and probably to reolve many hard quetions, not as yet o rightly determined. But becaue contemplations of this kind, are, in their own Nature, very unprofitable, if not reducible to practie: I have, as well as I could, applied the ame to the cure and prevention of mot dieaes: as will omewhat more at large appear by the enuing Treatie. Which I have uffered to undergo the publick view, with this aurance, that if the founda
• ion I build on, fail me not, I need not at all ••• bt the Supertructure.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of Fermentation in General.
div.p:
1. BY Fermentation, I undertand that motion obervable in all compound or mixed bodies whereby the order and itu •••
on of all the minute parts of the ame, are continually changed, as well in repect of themelves, as of the whole Mas whereof they are parts: and that, chiefly from an internal caue o moving or dipoing them, (without the local motion of the whole) whether the ame be accompanied with any enible heat, in the Mas o fermented, or not.

2. That uch a motion or fermentation <> every where obervable, we need not go <> to prove, if we conider, that there is
carce any thing ublunary, which is ubject to our obervation, that continues the leat moment of time in the ame tenour without alteration, which, if not obervable to ence is yet found to be o, with as little reaoning as that the hadow upon the Dyal continually moves on, though our eye determine not, till after ome minutes, perhaps, of time, it becomes apparent, that the hadow has moved and then we traight conclude it moved all the while: and that the proportional parts of pace, were commenurate to the repective moments, in which the hadow paed from one term to the other: if therefore all bodies are thus moved or fermented at all times, it fol
• ows that the Doctrine of Fermentation (according to our acception of the word) <> manner as far extended as that of <> itelf. I hall only conider it o <> as it eems conducible and ubervient to thoe noble ends I have propoed my elf in this Treatie, viz. the continuation of health, the cure of Dieaes, and the retard
• ng of old Age (to ay no more, and not • o promie too much) by a new and hitherto unheard of method.

3 The mot general properties of fermentation are thee: that the Mas o fermented uffers an eminent alteration in all its uual wayes of affecting our enes, as well in its firt as econd qualities: they are either exalted or depreed, they are ometimes changed for their contrary, and in a word, relation being had to our eteem of things thus fermented, all fermentation may be aid to be either perfective or detructive, though in it elf it be but one continued flux: as for intance in an apple, or the like, that from a green autere bud, firt acquires its due perfection, and after by a continuation of that fermentation, that ripened it, at lat arrives at corruption, and o changes both its name and nature together.

4 Another eminent property of fermentation, is that for the mot part the Body fermented doth occupy more pace than the ame did before, which is very evident in the drowned bodies of men or other animals, which though at firt they go to the bottom, yet after a certain time do lowly boye themelves up again to the top of the water, not for that the breaking of the
Gall becomes the caue of their acending: (as ome even knowing men have uffered themelves to be perwaded) but becaue uch bodies formerly heavier than water, quantity for quantity, and conequently apt to ink, have now acquired a larger dimenion, while they however increae not their weight, and o becoming lighter than the water contained in the like pace are protruded by it to the top where they by degrees well yet bigger o that ometimes I have een a dog lye with more than one halfe of his body above the urface of the water, and it is no more than happens in a pound of Glas, metal or other heavy material, which in a olid Mas inks to the bottom, but if blown or wrought into a bottle, it keeps the top of the water: all which together with the reaon is well enough known to uch as have been converant in tatick Experiments.

5 Another very ueful property of Fermentation is, that while it eparates all Heterogeneous parts, it leaves the Bais as it were, or main ingredient of the Mas clear and limpid, if not hindred by the denity of the body, and throws off two recrements
or uperfluities, one a heavier decending to the bottom, the other of a lighter more frothy ubtance, which takes its place at the top of the liquor: as is manifet in Wine, Sider and the juices of other fruits: in Beer made with Barly, and the decoctions of other grains, firt, maulted and grown'd. This happens not in Bread becaue the greatet part of the Mas being the more olid, the les or watry par • takes its flight on all ides to the circumference, though omewhat more lowly and there coagulates into a blew mould.

6. Another noble property of Fermentation, is, that it exalts the body fermented to what perfection it is capable of, but then it is requiite that the body fermented be of uch a conitence, as may not be fermented too fat, as in fruits, upon trees: or if thin, that it be cloe top't in ome full Veel, as all kind of drinks: or if o •
<> middle conitence, that it be often tirred which is oberved by Apothecaries in the making of Treacle, and other uch Compoitions, which afterward will keep a very long time. For thus it is neceary, that that pirit (as we will call it for the preent)
which ferments the Mas, be for a while detained either by the tone of the body, by ome trong veel; or that it be often re-effued, as it were, upon its body, that o by its long, difficult and reiterated working, it may at lat find out ome congruity amongt the les Heterogeneous parts, and caue a kind of complanation of the whole Mas, and it elf with les reluctancy, be detained in the Body or Mas.

7. Another very General property of Fermentation is, that all bodies, almot by it, at lat become acide: as is manifet in all liquors, decoctions of fleh, or herbs, electuaries, irups, &c. by which acidity I undertand not that owre tate, obervable in mot green fruits, which is rather to be termed acerbity, and differs as much from what we here peak of, as Agreta (the juyce of green grapes expret) doth from Vinegar.

8. In the next place, let us briefly conider the caues of Fermentation, the mot immediate of which, eems to be the Air, contained in every mixt body: for as I noted before, all bodies fermented, do occupy a larger room, than they did before
fermentation: which cannot be duely acribed, to any other ingredient in mixt bodies, than to the air, for that it hath not yet been found, by ufficient experiment, that any body whatoever is capable of rarifaction and condenation; or dilation and contruction beides air: as for Leaf Gold, what it got in one dimenion, it lot in the other, and all the parts of Gold calcined, do but equal the Mas they were made of, no more than if the ame had been reduced to an impalpable powder by means of a very fine file. The ame is to be undertood of water evaporated by heat: which is only a comminution of it, into exceeding mall parts, and no way a converion of it into air (as hath been formerly received) which is from hence evidenced, that uch vapours by the Alembic, are again reducible to the ame liquors from whence they were firt raied, viz. into Roewater or pirit of Wine, which were no more poible, if they had been really converted into air, then out of common air to draw Roe-water or pirit of Wine, and if water, or milke or other liquor take up more room when boyling on the fire, then they did
cold, 'tis by reaon that the particles of air, formerly not viible are now coniderably dilated, o as to become obervable to the eye.

9. As the Air contained in mixt bodies, is the mot immediat efficient caue of Fermentation: o it needs, exciting and actuating, for the mot part, as well by the temper and tone of the Medium, as from the addition, of this or that particular Ferment as of leven yeat, Renet, or the like: of which perhaps we hall have farther occaion to peak more, hereafter, and at preent only conider how the Medium epecially the Ambient Air, excites the internal air in the work of Fermentation.

10. By the Tone of the Air, I undertand the meaure of its rarity and denity and epecially its reciprocations or frequent acces and reces to this or that degree of rarity and denity. Now, that one Air is rarer than another as that of hills, then that of the valleys, that of outhern Regions, then that of the more Northern: is I think an undoubted truth: alo that the Air of every particular place is ometimes rarer ometimes dener according to the
everal eaons of the year, times of the day and night, &c. needs no other proof then that of the Weather-glas. By the temperature of the Air, I mean its degree and difference of heat and cold, which admits of the ame coniderations of place and time as before, and is not only proved by the Weather-glas, but even by ene it elf.

11. The manner how the Ambient works upon the internal air in mixed bodies, is the ame with that of the Weather-glas, where the incloed air is rarified, and condened, heated and cooled accordingly, as the Medium is affected: So in bodies fermented, epecially liquors, the imperceptible particles of air being gently and by degrees dilated, become the caue that the whole Mas doth occupy more and more room, or encreaes its dimenions under the ame weight, whereupon this effect immediately follows, that everal Heterogeneous Particles, which before floated in the liquor, and were (as I may ay) equilibrous with the ame, do now gently decend toward the bottom, in order, according to their weight: The mall Particles of air in
the mean while being more and more dilated do, together with the more vicous parts of the liquor (of which they form themelves Coats or Integuments) gently acend to the top of the Mas, where they make that frothy head or cum obervable in Sider, Wine, Beer, and other liquors; and this I take to be the natural method of all ferment • tion when not checked, or otherwie determined by ome outward circumtance: And this alo eems a genuine reaon of the depuration, and of the cating off the heavier and lighter recrement mentioned before (N. 5.) to happen in fermented liquors.

12. That Bodies are ripened and acquire their due perfection by fermentation, is aerted N. 6. but in uch cae it is neceary, that this fermentation be checked or retarded in uch ort as is there mentioned, both in natural and more artificial fermentations: But the mot univeral Moderator of this motion, is what was lately call'd the tone of Air, as well as its temperature, which daily and hourly changing, doth accelerate, retard, check and put backward this motion, and then retores it again; by
which various, and oft repeated coure, the parts are comminuted, their roughnes retunded and mitigated, and they o dipoed of, after an inexplicable manner, as conduces mot to the beauty and perfection of the Body fermented.

13. This dilatation and contriction in Bodies fermented, caued by the like accidents of the Ambient Air, may not improperly be compared with the pule in Animals having its Sytole and Diatole, even as they have, though by longer periods, as of day and night, warm weather and cold, &c. and from hence perhaps is the true caue of pules in Animals to be lookt for, which yet as forreign to our preent cope we here enquire not farther after; but it will not be improper to oberve (with common experience) that Malt is bet made in windy weather, and that the bet and mot lating Beer is brewed in March and September, (windy moneths, and of an unequal temper) Now 'tis evident, that all winds are moved by guts rather then equal fluxes (from whence probably it is that the Sea is lifted into Waves, as it were numbring to us the everal
impetuous troaks it received from the winds.) Thus the motion of all Animals eems to be performed by natches and jerks; and it is indeed a great quetion among School-Philoophers, whether any local motion be (trictly peaking) continual, and not rather coniting, of hort motions, and frequent rets, as it were compounded together. This Pule, or frequent change in the tone of the Air, however it may eem at firt view an idle or over-ubtil contemplation, will upon due conideration, be found not only true, and the caue of thoe effects aigned to it in the foregoing Paragraph, but that it may alo with good effect be made ue of in Phyick, as a notable intrument for preervation of health, and the cure of dieaes. I hall hereafter endeavour to prove in the enuing dicoure. That mot liquors fermented, epecially in the beginning, conceive heat, and become warm, even to ene the reaon, may be partly gathered out of what has been already aid; namely, that the mall particles of Air in uch liquor become dilated, which dilatation is always accompanied with an encreae of heat, they mutually
making way for, and introducing one the other (in the Air and bodies participating of Air) if not hindred from without; to which may be added, that all motion is apt to beget heat in the Body moved, which is true not only of olid Bodies, though more eminently in them, but alo of liquid Bodies themelves. Thus 'tis aid in making Butter, you mut neither make too much at once, nor yet mut it be too violently beaten or haken, for in uch cae there will be great hazard of over-heating the Butter, which as you ee is the meer effect of motion in a liquid Body only Beides mot liquors fermented, abou • with a kind of Tartar (which afterw ••• ubideth when the Mas begins to co •… the colliion of whoe rough particles <> againt the other, may perhaps omew •… contribute to the production of this he •… though I for my part impute les to <> then the caues before aigned, though <> remarkable heat ariing in Aqua fortis a •…
ed upon filings of Iron or Silver, is perh •… bet made out by the colliion of its apro •… parts againt thoe of the aid Metals.

14. As concerning particular ferments, I
hall only oberve, that congenerous Bodies uffer mot, and are bet fermented by their own proper ferments, namely Ale by yeat, Dough by Leven, Milk by Renet. Thus Apples, Pears and Grapes, and generally all fruit, once corrupted or rotten, do more eaily affect and putrifie thoe of their own kind then of any other; I ay more eaily, for they will, though with more difficulty, and after a longer time, corrupt fruits of a divers kind alo; and thoe particular Levens before-mentioned, will in like manner (though probably not o naturally) ferment • ther Bodies of whoe kind they are not: •… s Yet will ferment Dough (which yet <> omething congenerous to it, as pro •… ng it elf originally from Corn or <> ;) and whites of Eggs bea •… up <> nowy froth, will indifferently upply •… ant of Yet, in either Wort or Dough; •… am verily perwaded, that the Yety <> which may be taken off the top of <> running Drills of water, would effect •… me mingled with Dough, unles per
•… it be not vicous enough, wherein it •… ms only to differ from the whites of • ggs beaten as is aid; and it were worth
the trying to undertand, whether a Mas of Dough made with flower and now only, would need any other raiing or Leven. I have read, that in the Countryes about Parma and Piacenza, whence thoe o much valued Parmian Cheees come, the people make ue of Snow intead of Renet. This intance however of the white of an Egg beaten, may erve very well to illutrate our Poition concerning the fermentation of Bodies by the dilatation and contriction of its aereous Particles: as alo the kneding of Dough, and haking of liquors (which is a kind of kneding too) the better to make them rie and work, will notably confirm what we aid of the Tone of the Air, its frequent alterations, and of windy weather, how much they conduce to the better fermentation of mot Bodies.

15. Note, that the reaon why the juices of mot fruits do oon after expreion acquire a trong fermentation, eems to be this, that not only the liquor is now more at liberty, then when mixed with the flehy parts of the fruit, but likewie that the Airy Particles lay very much compreed in the fruit, every particular Grape,
Cherry and Apple, being in the nature of a little Bottle, which as we ee, if well topt, hinders the working of Ale or Wine, but once opened, the liquors traightway ferment and well very impetuouly, the compreed Air forcibly dilating it elf; and this is the reaon that fruit a little eaten by the Birds or Snails, will ripen much fater than if they had not been entered upon, (but then the tate will not be altogether o generous and prightly.) Thus Apples and Pears gather'd green and hoarded, ripen ooner far, than if they had continued hanging on the Trees, for that they now receive ome vent at their talks; and I find the Ancients were wont to plant the Caprificus (or wild Fig-tree) neer their other dometick Fig-trees, that o the Flees which in great quantities are bred out of the fruit of the Caprificus, may eize and pierce the Figs of the other trees, as they do in everal places, thereby not only accelerating their time of maturity, but alo (which perhaps is particular to this kind of fruit) rendring them much more tender and delightful than otherwie they would have been, had no uch Artifice been made
ue of. Now as we have aid, this kind of fermentation whereby fruits attain their maturity, bears a very due proportion with that oberved in botled drinks, which if well topt are lower in ripening (but of better tate) than in open veels: as alo if placed in cold well-vaulted Cellars, then if expoed to the Air: and that for this reaon, that the difference of heat and cold (epecially in Summer) is by many degrees more in the open Air, than in uch ubterraneous Vaults, and conequently the Aerous Particles, contained in uch fermented liquors, are more dilated and contricted (reciprocally) when expoed to the weather, than if laid up in Cellars, or buried in the ground. Which reciprocation of the tone of Air, we have already aerted to be the principal, if not the only caue of all fermentation. And it may be farther illutrated, by a common practie of botling up Wine, or other drink, with a lump of Loaf-ugar in it, which will make it much more brisk and lively. And this it d • th, not by its weetnes ure, for that were apter to clog and tame it, as is found by practie; or if it did, then Syrup of Sugar, or a mall quantity
of powder Sugar, might indifferently produce the ame effect: which yet is contradicted by experience. Nay, I dare confidently affirm, that the like quantity of the fame Loaf-ugar, firt done into very fine powder, will not erve the turn. So that I cannot imagine other reaon, why the lump of Loaf-ugar is of that ue, put into botled wine, &c. than that being very porous, it conveys with it elf, a great quantity of air into the liquor: and does in effect no more, than what has been already aid of the whites of Eggs beaten up together into a froth. So it is not the Sugar, but the air contained in the ugar, which mends the fermentation of the drink, and whereby the Sugar upplies the place of an additional ferment, the better to excite the working of the liquor.

16. And latly, methinks it might alone erve turn, to convince us of the great efficacy the air hath, and the power it exercieth on all or mot mixed Bodies: what we finde to manifet by experience in preerving of fleh, fruits, the Bodies of Inects, and other the like, whether for aliments or curioity only, and that with little
other preparation many times, than by barely immering them in wax, oyl, butter, ewet, ome Gum or Roine, &c. and afterward carefully putting them up into Veels well topped. By which practie we eem to obtain little ele, than that we do hereby, as it were, conceal thoe Bodies, thus preerved, from the air, which would otherwie, in a hort time, have totally corrupted them: their long continuance and preervation eeming to follow, as the conequence of that artificial excluion of the air, whereby the Bodies (or rather the air in them) are no longer apt to be affected, according to the various dipoitions of the Medium.

Farther, it is well worth our Obervation, that Chyle, Milk, Cream, the eeds of all Vegetables, and even that of Animals it elf, eem to owe their whitenes, to the interperion or diemination of air only: even after the ame manner, as is already oberved in Snow, and ome other Bodies.

div.head: CHAP. II. That Chylification is a ort of Fermentation, and how ditribution is performed.
div.p:
1. THe Stomack or Ventricle in animals, deigned by Nature for the Office of Chylification, commonly called the firt Concoction (and which is, as it were, the root of all Vegetation or nutrition in them) eems at firt birth but ill fitted for uch a work, till the Coats or Membrances thereof, have been well tained or eaoned by the receipt of an aliment o prepared, that it want little more than warmth, to the perfecting of that operation upon it, which is expected from the Stomack. And thus, for all animals that uck, Nature has provided for their firt food, a kind of corrupted Milk, uually called Beatings, which gives, as it were, the firt tincture to their tender Stomacks, and whereby they eem enabled to concoct more perfect Milk,
which they begin to draw after a day or two. Which Milk alo by degrees becomes more thick and harder of concoction, proportionably to the encreae of trength, in the tomack it elf, till by little and little, they begin to alter their diet, and forake the Teat, for uch other food as is mot proportionable to their repective Natures.

2. This Tincture, thus imprinted on the Stomack, may very properly be termed a ferment, and eems to bear a jut proportion with Leven, which is a mall part of the Mas of Dough, uffered to grow owre, while the ret is converted into bread, which if not hindred, would have all turned into leven likewie. Thus after the Chyle is conveyed from the Stomack into the Guts, from thence to be ditributed through the whole Body: ome mall part that remains ticking to the coats of the Stomack, oon after acquires that acidity, due to all fermentation not interrupted: which after ome time begins to grieve and afflict the Stomack with its harpnes: the ene whereof, we uually call hunger: which ene of pain (or hunger) continues to grow more and more, (that which caued
it becoming till harper and harper) till by the reception of new aliment, the acidity of the aid Tincture or Leven, be o mitigated and allayed, that the Stomack being, as it were, healed by application of thee new, benigne, and uncorrupted juices, is no longer enible of any pain or moletation: which then puts an end to the deire of eating. But if food be forborn, or withheld, the pain o long encreaes, till it at lat detroys the ene of the part, and introduces a phalelus, Gangrene or Mortification in the Stomack: which is afterward oon conveyed to the heart and brain, by its communion of Veels, and o at length becomes the death of the Animal. Which eems rather to be the caue of death, in uch as perih by hunger, than the emptines or inanition of the Veels, which, though much exhauted, are yet found in uch caes, with a coniderable quantity of blood in them. Nay, 'tis a frequent practie in the Dearts of Arabia (as I am informed by ome that have travelled in the Levant) to let their Camels blood after everal days fating, and to give them their own blood to drink, as the lat means left
to preerve their lives. Which practie, as it cannot replenih the veins, to that meaure it already emptied them: o it evidently concludes, that emptines of the Veels, is not the true caue, of perihing for want of food. Much les can the continuation of Suction, from the exhauted Veels to the Stomack, be the caue of hunger. For firt, uch hunger could not be immediately appeaed after eating, the Veels receiving no part thereof, till a coniderable time after, when ditribution begins to ucceed concoction, as is well known and confeed. Secondly, 'twill appear to uch as hall duly conider it, that the Veels or Veins are then fullet, when the Stomack is emptiet (& è contra) the emptying of the Stomack, beginning with the filling of the Guts, and Veins. Nor hall we need other arguments, againt this Suction (though it were eaie to charge it with more difficulties) than that the owners of it, will be forced to prove, there is ome uch power of moving by attraction, drawing or Suction, which will be a harder matter than it appears at firt ight. Though as not making to our preent purpoe, I hall not determine ought, concerning it.

3. In confirmation of this our Aertion viz. That the concoction of the tomack is a kind of fermentation, it will not b • amis to hew the reaon of ome circumtances of it. And firt, concerning that preparation, which meat receives in the mouth, by chewing or jawing of it, which is rather a bruiing than mincing: and it is a common obervation, that fleh minced very mall, is of much harder concoction, than if eaten by bigger pieces; and a ufficient reaon is withall aigned, that meat minced, lips down into the tomack, before it be duly maticated or chewed, which is o neceary an antecedent of concoction, that the Arabian Phyitians are wont to ay, That he that chaws not his meat well, hates his own Soul. Now that any thing bruied will oon after corrupt, is evident in all fruits: which will ooner putriie, after bruiing, than if they were cut with a harp knife into many pieces. Thus a fleh-wound, made without bruiing, will commonly heal again with little or no corruption, but not if the part were bruied at the ame time. Thus the common practie is to bruie Whitloes, to ripen and break them the ooner. And
thus to conclude, our meat by being brui
• ed, becomes of much eaier and peedier concoction, which eems to be the reaon why Nature has given to mot Creatures, namely, Dogs, Wolfes, Swine, Foxes, &c. three orts of teeth; to wit, Tusks to kill their prey with, harp fore-teeth or cutters, wherewith they tear it into maller pieces: And latly, Grinders to chew and bruie it, the better to prepare it for the tomack.

Birds eem to grinde their meat in their Gizards, after it is firt well oaked in their craps, for which purpoe they pick up harp tones, and their tomacks are made of two large Mucles; one, on either ide: the chief intruments in this work of Moliture, or grinding. The Locuta or Lobters has his teeth placed in his tomack, and o have the ret of that kind, which they imploy for the ame purpoe.

4. Our next obervation hall be upon two Rules of Diet, commonly given by Phyitians: the one is, that we hould not put new meat into our tomack, till after a perfect digetion of what was eaten the meal before: the reaon of which Rule,
eems to be this; That it is neceary th • tomack, hould continue ome time empty, that o the Fracid Tincture, or mall corrupted remaining portion, of the former meat, may have acquired its due acidity: whereby it may the better help the ucceeding fermentation or concoction. And it is no more than if you hould advie the Houe-wife, not to make any new Bread till the Leven be grown ripe, or owre enough to leven and ferment the Mas of Dough. The econd Rule is, that we hould leave eating, with ome mall appetite to eat on; or that we hould rie from Table with an appetite: the reaon is almot the ame with the former, and may well be illutrated by the ame intance, which is, that it is requiite, the Leven hould bear ome jut proportion, to the Mas it is to ferment. Thus if we rie with an appetite, it will appear that we have not over-charged this ferment of our tomacks, for appetite being, as is aid, a ene of pain caued by the harpnes of this acid ferment; it follows, that this acidity is not yet quite obcured by the late mixture of good, and conequently the tomack, not charged with
more, than may be well digeted, at once by <> . And thee are Rules, very fit to be oberved, as well by thoe which are of a more robut nature, as of them (epecially) who have weak tomacks, and find themelves indipoed after eating.

5. 'Tis further advied by ome Phyitians, that uch as have weak tomacks, hould forbear drinking, till they have neer dined: and we commonly oberve, that drinking jut before dinner, poils our eating, which it does, by diluting this ferment of the tomack, whereupon the ene of pain, and conequently hunger, abates very much, or quite ceaes for a time. And 'tis uually een, that they who are great Drinkers, are bad Trencher-men: and that as well, for that much drinking relaxes the tone, and extenuates the coats of the tomack, as more epecially, for that it wahes away by little and little, all this fracid tincture, or owre ferment, of the membranes thereof, which is as well the caue of concoction, as of appetite or hunger.

6. Bulls Blood drunk, was found a preent poyon by the Ancients, and Milk taken plentifully, and after curdling on the tomack,
has often been the caue of great and mortal Surfeits: the reaon of both is the ame; for that, both blood and milk being curdled, and brought into one hard lump, becomes inuperable to the tomack. Whereas, if the ame be uffered to coagulate (before they be eaten) and broken into mall parts, they will have no uch effect, and intead of poyoning, will afford an indifferent good nourihment to the body: So far eems Helmont to have mied the mark, when he ays, The caue of this poyon is, Imago Irae, in Sanguine Taurino. And I doubt not but a lump of Beef, or a piece of Cheee, of the ame bignes, whole in the tomack, would as urely poyon, if not more effectually. And this may farther confirm, what is aid in the third paragraph, of preparing our Food, by chawing, &c.

7. The inward membranes, or skins of the Gizards of mot Birds (epecially uch as feed on corn) prepared, by drying and powdring them, are held a great help to concoction. Now the acidity of them is very manifet, and no doubt they do no otherwie comfort our tomacks, than by encreaing and corroborating that ferment o
often mentioned. Thus, the dung of everal Animals prepared, namely of Wolves, Dogs, Peacocks, &c. have been approved of in divers dieaes, or ditempers of the tomack and guts, for the ame caue. Nay, I have heard that Paracelus, his Occidental Civet prepared, will make an excellent Peptick, for them that can dipene with uch homely remedies.

8. It is a famous Quetion among Phyitians, Whether it be better to make a meal of one only dih of meat, or to eat of everal meats at the ame etting? and it is commonly determined, in favour of the impler diet. But it eems more cononant to our Opinion, to allow rather of everal dihes; for that which is eaie of concoction, will help to concoct that which is harder. Thus good Sauces to meats make them et eaie, and light, upon the tomack: the Sauces (being eaie of concoction) helping the diolution of the meats. And we may urely expect, a heartier nourihment from them, than ingle dihes; as we find by experience, better broth to be made of everal orts of fleh, than of any one; and commonly the more variety, the more perfect
is the pottage. And its well known, we are nourihed by juices only, and not by the olid part of our food.

9. Where this ferment of the tomack is more acid than is requiite (as it is in Hypochondriacal perons, and uch as are troubled with owre belches) 'tis found by experience, that to make two, three, or four meals in a day, is better than one: and that fating encreaes much the acidity. Tha • hard meats, as dry bread, Bicuits, and thoe that are les eaie concoction, are more ueful than Broths (and other light meats:) which will ometimes (epecially taken in a morning, the ferment after long emptines becoming extraordinary owre) work o violently, that they will flow up into the mouth, and with their eagernes, et the teeth an edge, and ferment the very ground. But both in this, and the former rule, 'twill be neceary to take ome care, that we do not eat much more of our Many dihes, than we hould have eat of one, and that the quantity of our meat, at many meals, but equals, or not much exceeds, what we hould have eaten at once or twice.

10. 'Tis oberved, that udden change of diet has ometimes proved very fatal, and been often the occaion of dangerous dieaes. The reaon may well be, that the tomack, having received its tincture or ferment from food of another nature, is but ill prepared for the concoction of thoe meats, to which it hath not been accutomed, and from which it has as yet received no tain or impreion. Such changes therefore mut be made by degrees; and thus I have heard, that hores have been brought to live upon fleh: and ome men, have indifferently well upported life, with bread and herbs only.

11. Wolves are aid, when preed with extremity of hunger, ometimes to tear the ground, and fill their panches with meer earth: which urely affords them little or no nourihment. But it erves for the preent, to abate the edge of their appetites, till they meet with ome prey, at which time, they eaily dicharge their tomacks of the earth, and fall to better meat. This intance may indifferently well upport our Aertion, that hunger is rather a ene of pain from the acid ferment
of the tomack, than of emptines from the Suction of the veins.

12. As concoction ucceeds bet with ret, o motion is aid to help ditribution Now by ditribution, we are to undertand the dipering, of the thinner parts of the Chyle into the milky veins, from thence into the Subclavials, thence into the right Ventricle of the heart, where the Chyle already is pretty well tained, or imperfectly mingled with blood: from whence it takes its coure to the lungs, where by the reciprocations of that part, it is yet more perfectly, mixed with the blood. From the lungs, it decends into the hearts left Ventricle: from whence, it is thrown into the Arteries: where by degrees it receives the form and name of blood: and by them is conveyed into all parts of the body. In regard the milky veins, have no attractive power, whereby the Chyle might be uckt into them (as far as could yet be fairly made appear) nor has the Chyle (much les) any uch inclination or power of moving it elf that way; it remains, that this ditribution of the Chyle, is performed by the motion of the body. And thus we find moderate
exercie, oon caues an emptines in the •… irt ways, and begets an appetite. And yet we may likewie oberve, that while we it till, or leep, this ditribution is performed, though not o peedily. Now while we ret, there is no other motion oberveable, beide that of breathing, which eems to be the true caue of this ditribution of the Chyle, till it comes into the Subclavials: for when we draw in our breaths, the Diaphragme or Midriff compreeth the tomack, and gently forceth the Chyle thence into the guts. And again, when we breath out, the Mucles of the belly traight ubide, and trongly compres the guts; whereupon the thinner part of the Chyle ininuates it elf into the mouths of the milky veins, and by the ucceeding parts of the Chyle, is protruded into the Subclavials, where afterward it is moved with the motion of the blood. I do not deny the Peritaltick motion of the Intetines, (whereby the guts ditended with Chyle beyond their due tone, do again by their tranvere fibres contract themelves) for this is alo a partial caue of ditribution (as appears in the diection of live Animals,
where this motion of the Chyle continues after the Abdomen or belly is laid open from one end to the other) but is much trengthened, no doubt, by the Mucles of the belly; beides this Peritaltick motion of the guts, hews indeed in part how they are emptied, but not how they are fitted with Chyle, which is the firt part of ditribution.

13. 'Tis worthy obervation, that Butter melted, and very well beaten (or drawn) the while, becomes a much pleaanter caue, and eaier of digetion, than if it be not beaten; and yet all the difference is, that by beating a great quantity of Air, is every where mingled with it, whereby it very much helps the fermentation or concoction of our meat in our tomacks, after the ame manner as is already aid of whites of Eggs, in the former Chapter; and indeed all aues are a kind of additional ferments. That there is great quantity of air in Butter thus beaten, may not only be gathered from hence, that after beating, it takes up more room than it did before, or otherwie would do, if not beaten; but the ame particles of air are even manifet to
ene it elf, and the whole Mas of Butter appears, beaten up, into a froth, o far is • t from being made thicker thereby, (as we commonly expres our Opinions of it) • hat indeed it becomes much thinner and lighter, if compared quantity with quantity, as is manifet.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of Repiration.
div.p:
N. 1.THat Animals breath not at all, while in the womb, is mot probable, that all viperous creatures, after the birth, cannot live long without breath, is mot certain; yet I do not find the ues of Repiration o clearly determined, but that it may afford us matter for farther enquiry. The common received Opinion is, that Repiration erves chiefly for cooling the heart, next that, it yields matter for production of new vital pirits; and latly, that it dicharges the lungs of a fuliginous
excrement, which eems to tranude from the Mas of blood into the branches of the rough Artery: that the heart is cooled by breathing, is very probable, but not immediately; for the air going no farther than the lungs, firt cools them, next the blood in them, and conequently the heart becomes les hot, than otherwie it would be; but this is, in effect, no more than is obtained by bathing the limbs in cold water, which does a together (if n • t more effectually) cool the Mas of blood, as much as the air in breathing can be conceived to do it, and yet bathing will in no wie become a Subtitute to breathing. Nor does the generation of vital pirits eem to be the chief ue of the air in breathing, in regard it is not eaie to conceive any uch contrivance in the lungs, that may erve for the letting in of air, into the veins and arteries, which contain the blood, without endangering, contrariwie, the effuion of that precious juice, much les has Anatomy, as yet, dicovered any uch paages unto us. Latly, as I hall not deny, but that the lungs do dicharge themelves of a fuliginous excrement by breathing; o I
think it as true, that this is none of the principal ues of Repiration. Nor is it at all likely, that either the heart hould grow o hot, or that the vital pirits hould vanih o fat, or the fuliginous excrement be accumulated in that quantity, upon the intermiion of breathing for a hort time only, as to indanger our lives beyond recovery, as the abolute neceity of Repiration would eem to inforce. Before I come to deliver my own Opinion, I hall make a light digreion concerning the circulation of the blood, which will not a little illutrate what we are about to ay concerning this Subject.

2. 'Tis manifet in the circulation of the blood in Animals, that the blood is moved from the left Ventricle of the heart, through the great Artery, into all its branches, from whence it is brought back by the maller veins, which dicharge themelves into the Vena Cava, from whence it is returned into the right Ventricle of the heart, from whence it is ent by the Vena Arterioa into the lungs, and o brought back again into the left Ventricle of the heart by the Arteria Venoa: And in this
circular motion of the blood, life chiefly coniteth: and if the ame by any chance hould ceae or intermit, though but for a very mall time (les than a minute) death would unavoidably follow. In this motion of the blood, it is obervable firt, that as the pulation of the heart endeth it through the Arteries, into the whole habit of the body, o the return of it by the veins, eems to depend chiefly upon the tonical motion of the body; for the parts being extended by the flowing in of the blood, omewhat beyond their tone, do again gently ubide, and thereby continue the intended coure of the blood toward the heart again. An argument hereof is, that all Paralytick parts grow immediately cold, and that for no other reaon, than that the tonical motion, together with the power Locomotive, ceaing, the circulation is either very weakly, or not at all performed through that part, which then grows cold, for want of that contant freh upply of blood, which formerly kept it warm. But herein the tonical motion is not a little helped by exercie and labour, which we find, by experience, to caue the heart to
beat quicker and oftner, as alo to induce a neceity of breathing more frequently; and this it doth no otherwie, than by accelerating this circular motion of the blood, which then enforceth the heart and lungs to double duty. Our econd obervable in this circular motion of the blood is, that there paes as much blood from the right Ventricle of the heart into the • u • gs, at every pule (taking one time with another) as is ent from the left Ventricle into all the parts of the body beide. Nor can it be otherwie, the left Ventricle being upplied from the lungs only; and the lungs receiving it, not elewhere than from the right Ventricle of the heart. So, that to continue this circular motion of the blood, 'tis neceary, the upply neither exceed, nor come hort of that quantity, dipened from the left Ventricle of the heart, into the whole body (the Lungs excepted.) From hence it follows, that there flows a greater quantity of blood, by many degrees, into the lungs, than what is ufficient for its own private ue. As alo, that the blood in the lungs, mut of neceity, move very much fater, than it does in any part of the
body: though we take for example, the great vein or artery themelves: and that, in the ame proportion, as the Vena Arterioa, and Arteria Venoa, are maller than the trunks of the foreaid great veels. For, let the ame quantity of liquor be conveyed through a pipe, whoe capacity is but one fourth, or one tenth, o big as another pipe, through which the like quantity mut pas in the ame time: and it is evident, the liquor mut run four times, or ten times as fat, through the maller pipe, as it does through the greater. And thus, it appears, that a very coniderable part of the Mas of blood, is continually running through the Parenchyma of the lungs; and that, at a much wifter rate, than it doth, through any part of the whole body beide.

3. Farther, before we proceed to treat of the ue of Repiration, it will not be amis to conider, what kind of motion that is which the lungs are exercied with, in breathing. Nor is it any other, than a motion of dilatation and contriction; whereby the lungs are reciprocally opened and hut, omewhat after the manner, of a pair
of Organ-Bellows: the air entring into them, when dilated or opened, and receding again, upon their ubiding. And this is what we call Repiration. Nor yet, does this reciprocation of the lungs, proceed from any power to move, they are endowed with of themelves. For, if we conider, the frame and tructure of them, they will appear of a Parenchymous kind of ubtance, not much unlike the liver, and altogether void of Mucles; without which, no local motion can be performed. We may conclude therefore, that the lungs are moved by conent, and that chiefly of the Diaphragme or Midriff, in a free and ordinary breathing. But, in any difficulty of breathing, as in the Athma, Tabes, violent exercie, &c. not only the Midriff, but almot all the Mucles of the trunk of the body, namely, thoe of the Belly, Chet and Shoulders, eem to afford their aitance, in this great work of Repiration. The motion of the Midriff is firt downwards; whereupon the lungs follow, and the air is admitted, and again upwards; whereby the lungs are compreed, and the air excluded. Thus you ee, that as the contruction
of the Midriff, o is its motion, omewhat different from that of other Mucles: which, as being well known, we hall not need to pend longer time about, but come to the publick ue of the lungs, in the Oeconomy of our bodies.

4. In the circulation of the blood, we acribed the reduction of it again into the right ventricle of the heart, to the Tonical motion of the body: where yet, as we have aid, the blood moves but very lowly, if compared, with that wift, and rapid motion, it is carried on with, through the lungs; where it moves, perhaps, ten times as fat, as in any other part of the body; as has been already proved. Which notwithtanding, we hall not be able, upon perual of the tructure of the lungs, to conclude, that they are endowed with any coniderable tonical motion, as may be gathered, as well from their want of Mucles, as for that their ubtance, is very pongey and flaccid: and their common integument is but one thin membrane. Nor was it without a particular, and that a mot excellent deign: that Nature thus contrived the lungs with little or no tonical motion in them. For firt, had this Tone been equivalent to the
Mas of blood, to be returned by it; it would much have retarded the influx of the blood, into the lungs: and conequently, have hindered a great work of Nature upon it there, as hall be hewed hereafter. But chiefly, for that it has largely upplied uch defect, by the aitance of the Diaphragme which becomes the caue, both of dilating, and contracting the lungs; according to the occaion, and at the will and pleaure of the Animal. And this is, indeed, the firt and principal Office of the lungs; as to what concerns their reciprocal motion: Namely, that upon the ubiding of them, in Repiration, the blood may be vigorouly queezed out of them, through the Arteria Venoa, into the hearts left Ventricle. And becaue, the ubtance of the lungs is very tender; Nature contrives, that not the Diaphragme immediately, but the air incloed in the cavity of the bret (for this very purpoe only) being firt, treightened and crowded, as it were, together, by the motion of the Diaphragm upward, hould caue this compreion upon the lungs; while by its Elatic power, it endeavours to dilate it elf again, to
its uual dimenions. Nor could any way of compreing the lungs, (thereby to dicharge them of the uperfluous blood) have been contrived more equal: for this pent air, is as apt to pres upon one part, as on another. Nor yet more gentle, and ecure: for what contact could have been more delicate, or les apt, to wound the tender membrane of the lungs, than the air incloed in the bret about them? Nor need any doubt, but that the air, thus compret and treightned, is of trength ufficient for this ervice: and that there is uch a Spring in the air; who, hall but conider with what force, the air breaks forth of the Wind-gun, and other Pneumatic Engines. A farther confirmation hereof, may be had from hence: that uch wounds, as perforate the bret, if left open, but for a little time, do quickly caue a difficulty of breathing and I do not much quetion, but if both ides of the bret were perforated, it would as certainly dipatch a man, as hanging; and that, almot, in as hort a time. Farther, in the diection of live Animals, Repiration continues, long after the Abdomen or belly is laid open; but
immediately ceaes, upon dividing the Diaphragme or Midriff.

5. Whether the air, that enters into the lungs, by the Wind-pipe, have a hare in this compreion of them, for the dicharging of the blood, or not, I am as yet not well atisfied. At firt view, this compreion hould eem, to be bet made upon drawing in our breath; between the air implanted in the cavity of the bret, and the air, in the rough Arteries: (or branches of the Wind-pipe) but at uch time, the implanted air, is but little or not at all contracted: and therefore we mut conclude, that either the air taken in, bears no part in this compreion: or which is mot probable, that the anguine Veels of the lungs, are not only trongly compreed, upon expirations; but alo upon inpiration; that is, o often, as the lungs are removed from their natural, middle, or indifferent cituation: whether expanded or contracted. Viz. Tàm in quiete externâ, quàm internâ. We mut likewie allow the air to cool the lungs very coniderably, and that it dicharges them of a fuliginous, or rather vaporous excrement. But thee are,
• s we have aid, the les principal ues of Repiration. As for the airs becoming the matter of Vital Spirits in Repiration, I hall ay no more, than that I neither find any need of it, nor any may for the mingling of it, with the Mas of blood.

6. Allowing what has been aid, concern
• ng • he ue of repiration: we may, perhaps, •• nd out a more commodious reaon of ighing, than has been yet aigned. For, if a man hall for a while, either wholly forbear breathing: or, at leat, breath eldomer, • nd lower, than is his uual cutom: the • unges, in the mean time, well and fill • hemelves with blood, (for want, of that • requent and trenuous compreion, formerly equal to the influx of the blood,) while the pule is not o full as ordinarily: • he hearts left Ventricle not receiving its • ue upply from the lungs, which in this • ae receive more than they deliver: Here
• pon a man is neceitated, (for avoiding • uffocation) to fetch a great breath, or •• gh, which may more trongly, than uu
• lly, compres the ubtance of the lungs, • nd reduce them to their former etate. And thus, great attention, any deep contemplation,
ad thoughts, and a melancholick contitution; do often become the caue of frequent ighing: As alo, a natural loth, or les aptnes in the lungs themelves, or Diaphragme, to motion: will ometimes make this paion cutomary, and habitual. And it is obervable, that the pule ries very much upon ighing; for the firt troak, or two, at leat: the blood coming to the Artery again, in that abundance, that a man may feel the tingling of it, at his very fingers ends.

7. Furthermore, it may not a little trengthen our Aertion, that in all great difficulties of breathing: and where there is mot imminent danger of uffocation, to let blood in good quantity, is commonly precribed, as the lat remedy: and which eldome fails, of giving, at leat, a preent relief, let the caue be what it may be. And this it eems to do, by diverting the coure of blood from the lungs; while they gently again dicharge themelves of their burden. And in cae of hanging, or trangling, letting of blood in great quantity, has ometimes aved mens lives that have been executed; and this by no other ways, that
I can think of, than by helping to dicharge the lungs of their oppreion, as has been already aid.

8. And thus we have, if our Opinion fail us not, dicovered the true ue of Repiration. We have, alo of conequence, freed the heart, of almot one half of the task impoed on it, by the modern Phyitians. For ince the circulation of the blood conits of two parts, viz. Firt, the conveying it from the heart, or center, to the ret of the body, as to a kind of natural circumference. And econdly, the returning, or bringing back of the blood again, to the heart. The firt part, we conceive to be the Office of the heart. The econd part, eems to be the work of every particular member, to dicharge it elf of its own uperfluities: For which purpoe, nature hath endued them with a tone, or tonical motion, ufficient for that ervice, the lungs only excepted, wherein Nature hath worthily imployed her indutry, by the additional contrivance of Repiration, through the aitance of the Diaphragme: which labour of the lungs, in Repiration, for the returning of the blood to the left
Ventricle of the heart; eems to equal that of the tone, or tonical motion, of all the other parts of the body; for the lungs convey the ame quantity, with all the ret: that is to ay, the whole Mas of blood, through them; and that in as little time, as the ame paes through the ret of the body. And, if it carries it not o far, it moves • t o much the fater. And o, we hall have entitled the lungs, to one full quarter part, of this work of the circulation of the blood, leaving an other quarter to the tonical motion of the body: And the firt, and worthier half, of dipening blood and life through the whole body, to the heart, as its proper office and duty. What part, the lungs may jutly claim to themelves, in the buines of Sanguification, we hall more conveniently find place to conider of, in the following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Sanguification.
div.p:
N. 1.THe Chyle, when eparated from the remaining unprofitable parts of our Aliment is, by proper veels of its own (the dicovery of modern Anatomits) conveyed directly into the Subclavial veins, and from thence into the right Ventricle of the heart, where it is mingled with a larger quantity of blood, returning home by the great vein, together with which it is immediately tranmitted to the lungs, where (though it make great hat through, and moves very impetuouly, as has been aid, yet) by reaon of the length of the way, it continues a coniderable time, and is more perfectly mingled with the blood, and wrought up together with it, into one Mas, and at the ame time, acquires both the name and form of blood (as Phyitians term it) and o is fitted for the heart, from thence to be ditributed to the ret of the body: where after what manner it is circulated,
we ay not, as a thing already ufficiently known, and whereof we have delivered our ene already.

2. That Chyle is very eaily mixt with blood, is evident, for that it is the matter whereof all blood is made, by a farther continuation, of that fermentation or concoction, begun on it in the tomack. Nor yet is the proportion o great between them, but that upon mingling; the diimilitude of parts, becomes immediately the caue of an extraordinary ebullition: which is very much encreaed by the reciprocal motion of the lungs, whereby the blood is wrought almot all into a froth or foam, by that time it gets into the left Ventricle of the heart. Which udden exces of heat, is not unlike what happens upon the mingling everal Chymical liquors together, as Spirit of Wine, and Spirit of Turpentine, and other uch like, where the heat becomes o great, that it often endangers the veel they are contained in. And this is the caue of that heat a while after meals dicernable in Hectical perons, and others, otherwie affected: and which in many appears, by fluhings in the face. Now that
the blood is wrought up to that froth, we peak of, during its paage through the lungs, is not only uitable to reaon, but appears mot evidently, in thoe anguine excretions from the lungs, which happen in conumptive perons: nor does that frothines, then obervable, proceed from the mingling with it the air we breath, for that at one breathing out (or expiration) could not be ufficiently performed.

3. The blood, by everal very learned men, has not unaptly been compared to wine; and in my Opinion, the Chyle may as properly be likened to the juice, newly preed out of the Grapes: which if it were by certain intervals, in a due proportion, poured gently into new wine, or mut, as it begins to cool, would again renew its ebullition, and continue the warmth of it, to what degree is requiite, and that o long as this practie hall be continued. And from this Illutration may be clearly gather'd; the neceity and ue of eating, at leat within certain periods, or intervals: to wit, that by the frequent affuion of Chyle, the blood may again recover its motion, warmth and vigour, without which
upply, it would oon languih, cool and congeal, and conequently, death enue. Now that the lungs are indeed the principal Officina Sanguinis, may be farther collected from Conumptions of the lungs, wherein all parts of the body are o uddenly extenuated, by the affection of the part.

4. 'Tis probable, that the blood during its tay in the lungs, does not actually dilate it elf, and rie into froth, but only acquires an aptnes o to do, as oon as it is at a little more liberty, as appears in blood pit out of them; and conequently; when it falls into the left Ventricle of the heart, it immediately dilates it elf with great force, in the manner of botled Beer; and in this manner does, for ought I know, in great part, become the caue of the Diatole, or expanion of the heart, which being extended, beyond its due and natural cituation, does again violently contract it elf, by a power almot all bodies have of retoring themelves, and which we call the tone, or tonical motion. And as we oberve in a Switch bowed down, or in a Pendulum removed out of its place, that they return beyond the perpendicular; o it
fares in this motion of the heart, whereby it is again more contracted, than is natural to it, and o of it elf returns again to expand it elf, and is again violently ditended, as before, by the influx of more pumy blood from the lungs. Now though it may be objected, that the pule in the heart continues, many times, a long while, after it is taken out of the body; and when there is no longer any uch influx to be pretended, as the caue of it. To this I anwer, that uch pule, is what the Phyitians call the Myurus, or Moue-tail, for that its Diadromes, or differences, between greatet and leat expanion, do continually become les and les, even as it happens in Pendulums, once removed from the perpendicular, which continue their motion for a long time, after the hand is from them that firt et them awork. At leat this ebullition of the blood in the heart, eems not a little to contribute to the continuation and trengthening of this pulive motion. In contemplation of this Orgamus, or fury, as I may call it, in the blood iuing out of the lungs, and now to be ditributed into all parts of the body Nature contrived
the Arteries with thick and double coats, the better to contain it: whereas the veins deigned for the carrying it back again to the heart, at what time the blood is very much cooled and tamed, are only made of ingle membranes, as being ufficient now to hold it. And this is all the difference between Arterial and Venal blood.

5. It eems of all other Opinions the mot probable, that the blood, when arrived at the extremities of the mallet Arteries, is there hed upon the habit of the body, in the belly, or flehy part of every Mucle; each Mucle having the proportion, or likenes, of one of the quarters, or Acetabula in an Orange, or a Lemon; upon the compreion of which, either by local or tonical motion, it is not hard to conceive, how the blood is again forced into the mouths of the veins; and after the ame manner has every Mucle its particular membrane. And thus we find that blood iues forth, upon pricking the fleh, in any place; although it cannot be imagined, we hould always prick a vein or Artery: or we mut conclude, there is nothing
ele in fleh, but a multitude of capillar veins and arteries, which were aburd to be aerted.

6. To make hort: Life it elf is but a continuation of this vigorous fermentation of the blood, which is o long maintained, as the Mas of blood is kept hot, and circulating through the veins and arteries; and if done by thoe means, and in that manner, which is uitable to Nature, o long the body is in perfect health. If it be too violently fermented, or moved, it does, in general, become the caue of Fevers, and other acute dieaes: as contrariwie, if the fermentation be too weak, from thence all chronical dieaes take their original: and that particularly, according to the everal irregularities that may happen, either in exces, or defect, in this fermentation and circular motion of the blood. We decend not now to particulars, the mot we aim at in this Treatie, being but a general method, either of preventing or curing dieaes, after a way not yet treated of.

7. Since the dicovery of the circulation of the blood, it has been the Opinion of many great Aertous of it, that where the
indication is of letting blood, it matters not out of what vein it be taken, provided, o many ounces be let out, as the dieae requires. And this their Aertion is made probable, by many arguments alledged by them for that purpoe; and but for the tonical motion of the habit of our bodies, would be as great a truth, as any is in Phyick. But the tonical motion of the parts once admitted, We mut likewie grant, that thoe parts will empty themelves firt, that lie nearet to the inciion; as well, for that there is les trength required to force any liquor to a horter than a longer ditance: as alo, becaue the more remote parts, or Mucles, do exercie a kind of Antipraxia, or Contranitency, and o become of mutual impediment one to the other: whereas the nearer parts, do almot immediately dicharge themelves upon the Orifice, or inciion.

8. From this tonical motion of the whole body, it happens, that any particular part is ometimes preternaturally welled, either from a troak, the application of cupping-glaes, or generally any other caue, which may weaken the tone of the part; for in
uch cae, the heart continuing its motion, for the ditribution of the Mas of humors, it is very eaie to conceive, that more of them will pas into that part, where leat reitance is made, than otherwie would have happened, had the part continued in its natural tone and vigour.

9. From hence likewie the reaon is to be ought, how it happens in letting blood, that o large a quantity hould in o mall a time, iue out at the inciion made in one vein, and that perhaps none of the larget. For if we duly conider, how quickly a man may bleed to death, by the opening (for intance) of a vein in his arm; we mut conclude, that the blood paes not much fater through the heart, than it does at the ame time out at the Orifice in his arm; and that conequently, there is but little blood received, during this evacuation, into the ret of the body, which doth then by its tone dicharge it elf (into the great vein) of its Plethora, or uperfluous blood which returning again from the heart, toward the habit, the greatet part takes its way to the part, where the inciion was made, it finding
there no other oppoition, than what it has while it is travaated from the arteries into the veins, through the mallnes of their mouths, which yet is in part recompenced by the multitude of them. Now if it be agreed on, that in half an hour a man may bleed to death, or thereabout, if a vein in the arm be kept open: and that there will, in uch cae, be about one half of his blood let out, computing what is likewie contained in the capillar veels, and what remains in the habit of the body, it will follow, either that the whole Mas is compleatly circulated twenty four times in twenty four hours, or a natural day. Which eems a little too often, or that the blood circulates much fater, while a vein is breathing, than at other times, which is not improbable; or that a man may continue bleeding longer than half an hour, which is not o likely: or that there is not in uch cae of bleeding to death, one full half of the Mas let out: All which may deerve a more exact crutiny, but mut now be left to be decided by the experiments of uch, as are converant in the diection of live Animals.

10. It is frequently een in hores, that upon long and much labour, they loe the ight of their eyes; nay, I have known ome hores that have lot one or both eyes, with one days over-training, either by draught, or coure, and o became blinde of a udden. And then we commonly ay, they have drawn their eyes out: But how the eyes hould uffer, or what part they take in the labour, or violent exercie of the body, is not o eaily made out, unles by this tonical motion of the body, which now becomes much trengthened by the violent local motion, either in drawing, or running, whereby the Mucles of the whole body are much more compreed, than in their natural tate of ret, and conequently, do not only not admit of the uual quantity of blood and humours, due to them by circulation; but by their violent and frequent contraction, do return them back in much a larger proportion, than they now receive them; whereupon the lungs become over-charged, which caues frequent breathing, and makes the pule quicker and tronger than formerly, ditends the great vein and artery, with a
greater quantity of blood, than is uuall: Whereupon the Artery, by its pule, and tone endeavours to dicharge it elf upon the habit of the body, which not receiving it in its due and accutomed proportion, the blood does in a more than a uual manner, fill the veels of the eyes (and other weak parts) and either by diention, compreion, or extravaation of blood, or other humor, the order and dipoition of the parts of the eyes becomes o confued and diturbed, that no wonder if blindnes immediately, or oon after, do enue. Now 'tis manifet from hence, that where the body of an hore is clean, that is to ay, not o full of humors; and where blood abounds not over-much, this accident hall not eaily happen. And here we are to oberve, that though the native tone of the eye do rather exceed that of the other parts, than come hort of it, yet it is not ufficient to reit this influx, when the tone of the other parts is o much trengthened by the violent local motions of the body.

11. If we a little reflect upon the manner of the Circulation of the Blood, and
how by very modern dicovery, the Chyle is firt mingled with the blood, in the axillary or ubclavial veins, from whence it paes by the right Ventricle of the heart, through the lungs, into the left Ventricle; from thence to be ditributed into the whole body: One thing very remarkable will arie to our obervation; namely, that what part of the blood is ent toward the head by the carotides or arteries of the neck, flows thither very crude, and accompanied with all its excrements, it having not yet received or uffered any depuration, or alteration, from the Reins or Spleen, like that which paes into almot all other, epecially the lower parts of the body (though indeed it eems not to be cleaned of the gall, till it returns home again through the liver.) Now though Natures purpoe herein be very obcure, that the blood thus impure, hould be deigned for the ervice of the mot Noble part, yet, that o it is, will farther appear, by the everal Emunctories (or inks) wherewith the head is in a particular manner provided, as the ears, eyes, noe, palat; every of which, dicharge the brain of a everal excrement,
and that no longer ueful to the body, except what is ecerned by the palat, which is for the mot part again returned to the tomack: for the better eparating of which, Nature has indutriouly placed about the head, o many of thoe erous veels, called the Ductus Salivares, which eem here to perform the ame Office, to that part of the blood ent to the head, which the Reins do execute, to the remaining Mas. Hence no wonder it is; if exceive drinking do o much weaken the brain, caue Catarrhs (which is nothing but an over-flowing of the Ductus Salivares) weaken all the faculties of the Soul and enes, and at length, enervate the whole body, although, at the ame time, the Reins do their duty indifferently well; and this epecially, if the native tone of the brain be weak, it being then o much the les able to dicharge it elf of uch uperfluous excrements. This may be aid in general, that the blood is thus ent to the brain, before depuration, in regard of its publick Office, that the ame may there be farther elaborated, as hall bet uit with its ervice in that Noble part. Thus
much, by way of an ueful digreion, may uffice, concerning tonical motion, and ome coniderable circumtances of it; which as well for the aitance it gives the heart, in the circulation of the blood, as for the many ueful indications from thence ariing, in the Doctrine of Phlebotomy, was mot properly to be handled in this Chapter of Sanguification.

12. And now I do not much doubt, but whoever hall have carefully perued what has been lately aid concerning Sanguification, and the ue of the lungs; will as readily conclude with me, that the lungs do bear a very principal part in the work of Sanguification, for in them the Chyle is perfectly mingled with the blood; in them one half part of the circulation is performed; and in them the blood eems to free it elf, firt of all, from any excrement: to wit, a fuliginous, or rather a vaporous watry uperfluity (which paeth out together with our breath.) And this eems the firt and chiefet part of Sanguification. The econd, is a farther elaborating the Mas of blood in the arteries, which is performed by the pulive motion of the heart. The
third and lat part, is the depuration of the blood, whereby its uperfluous excrements are eparated from it: and this is performed by the ret of the bowels thus: by paing through the Reins, it is dreined of its erous parts: Another excrement it eems to leave behind it in the Spleen, though of what kind, is not yet well determined among the modern Phyitians: But on all ides it is concluded, that while it pae • through the liver, as through a Streiner, i • is there purged of choler, which in mo • Animals is collected in a little bladder, o • Citis; from whence it is tranmitted to th • Intetines, where it becomes a kind of natural Clyter, and provokes to the excerning the excrements of the firt ways, as they ue to term them. And this is what lay in our way, to ay at preent, concerning Sanguification.

div.head: CHAP. V. That often changing the Air, is a friend to health: Alo a dicovery of a new method of doing it, without removing from one place to another, by means of a Domicil, or Air-Chamber, fitted to that purpoe.
div.p:
N. 1.HAving hitherto hewed what part the air acts in all fermentations, and that in repect of its tone and temper: Viz. its difference of rarity, and denity, and of heat and cold; and that in general only: not conidering what other dipoitions of the Air may make it apt to promote or retard the motion of fermentation; whereby it may alo powerfully operate, to the continuation or detruction of mixt bodies: as not o directly erving for the illutration of the Subject, we principally intend in this dicoure. Having farther made it probable, that the work of our tomacks, upon our Aliments, as alo,
that Sanguification it elf, is a kind of fermentation. And latly, having aerted the publick Office of the lungs, together with the ue of breathing, as well in promoting the circulation, as elaborating of the blood. And having likewie aid omething of the tonical motion of the body; and all this, after a manner, omewhat different from what has been hitherto received, and taught in the Schools. It remains, that from thee Phyiological peculations, we proceed to raie ome medicinal concluions and contrivances, very ueful for the cure, as well as prevention of undry dieaes.

2. But firt it will be neceary, to premie, that the Atmophere, wherein we breath and live, is heavy or ponderous, and prees more or les, upon all bodies in it; and upon all ides expoed to it; and that epecially, according to its difference of rarity and denity.
