So that upon the tops of very high hills, and in bright weather, the Atmophere will lie lighter upon us; and all other bodies than the ame, will in thick weather, and in deep valleys; and conequently, that we move with more difficulty when the air is thick, and with more eae
when the ame is thinner; which is as much as to ay, that the reitance of the Medium is proportionable to its meaure of rarity and denity. All which we now take for granted, and hall pare our elves the pains of proving, as what has been already ufficiently made out by everal learned men in this our Age: from whoe writings uch as doubt, may receive very ample atisfaction. And we hall only conclude, that if all motion, be eaiet performed in the thinnet air, then in uch an air, we hall breath freer, diget our meat better, and be les tired with wa • king, or working, than in a thicker air: and conequently, perform all the functions of life better, as is indeed manifet, even to experience it elf. (which yet is wont, for the mot part, to take notice but of the more gros obervables) for who almot is there, of o happy a contitution, that during health it elf, and in the prime of his years, is not in ome meaure affected by the alteration of the weather, and by the change of the air? for, as for uch as are ick, the very moments of life and death, do eem to depend upon this change: and uch as are Valetudinary perons,
commonly find, to their great grief, that their own bodies, may indifferently well upply the want of a weather-glas, in admonihing them, not only of the changes of the weather, but of the eaons of the year alo. So very coniderable is this alteration of the air to all mixed bodies, epecially Animals, and among them, to men more particularly, as being les armed againt the injuries of the air, and among men mot of all, to uch as are infirm; as hath been aid.

3. Now if the Natural and Vital Functions are better and eaier performed in a purer air, than in a courer; no wonder, if upon changing the wore for the better air, many (epecially Chronical) dieaes, do by degrees from thence, receive a cure: which were before invincible, by other remedies: or mut have been patiently endured, till the alteration of the eaon of the year, introduce that change in the air, (as to its tone and temper) which is ufficient o to rectifie the motion of the humours in our bodies, as at length to overcome the ditemper. Which might poibly have ooner been obtained, by a eaonable removal into a wholeomer,
warmer, or drier Region. But it is much more remarkable, that not only the changing a bad air for a better, is available in uch caes; but much more the often changing of the air, though ometime for a wore, which is not only confirmed by experience, but likewie by the Authority of C. Celus, who trictly injoyns it, and adds this as a reaon, that if a man reide in o good an air, that he knows not where to remove to a better, yet it will be profitable for him to remove, and that often; for in cae of icknes, that may jutly be eteemed the wort air, as to the concernment of the Patient, in which the dieae took its beginning. The reaon (in gros) why changing the air at all, hould cure dieaes, may be this; that the body of man is capable of enduring a greater latitude, either in the tone or temper of the air, than what the dieae thus curable can conit with; and perhaps no other Animal is able to endure that variety of Climes, that a man may indifferently enjoy himelf in. And thus men are found to inhabit in all parts almot of the Inhabitable World, whereas other Animals are proper to this or that
particular Region, and will either die, if tranported into other places, or at leat loe much of their vigour, and not generate. The ame is alo obervable in plants. 'Tis aid, that Lice bred on this ide the Line, (or Aequator) will immediately all die on the other ide the Line: So that it follows, the Ptherais, or Lowie dieae, will be peedily cured by uch a change of the air or Clime: and all, or mot other dieaes, do eem to bear ome Analogy in their exitence, to the life of that depicable little Animal. But that the often changing the air, is o much a Nobler Remedy, than that of removing once for all into the bet air: The reaon is urely this, that firt, in the finer air, the motion of Fermentation of the humors, and juices of our bodies, is better performed, and omewhat accelerated; and again, a little retarded, by a peedy remove into a groer air, whereby the humors are, as it were, kneaded or carded; and the dieae at every uch change, receives a notable hake, which eems to be much more enible (if I may o ay) of every uch impreion, than our bodies are. And this often changing the air,
does well reemble the many troaks, which are neceary to fall the turdier Oak, while one or two, though very coniderable ones, are not ufficient to bring him to the ground. I hould therefore from hence conclude, that if once changing the air, do not in ome reaonable time give aurance of a cure, that then we doubt not, with the Judicious Celus, to change, as often as hall eem convenient, which urely will, (other helps not neglected) at length (provided the dieae be curable) put an end to, and wholly eradicate the ditemper, be it almot what it may be.

4. But it will not be amis, to be a little more particular, in hewing, after what manner the air works upon our bodies, and affects it with its everal alterations, and differences of rarity or denity. And firt, I think it wi • l be granted by mot men, and might be clearly proved by everal experiments, that there is a certain quantity of air in all liquors, inenibly dipered in very minute parts, through the whole Mas of them, which mall particles do actually ymbolize with the Medium; and will, by contracting or dilating themelves, caue
the liquor wherein they reide, to take up ometimes more, and ometimes les room: as will be manifet to him, that hall fill a large glas bottle, of about a pottle or more, with water, till it rie two or three inches in the neck, which will need to be very lender, and omewhat long, and it will oon appear, that the water hall ometimes rie, and at other times fall, almot after the manner of ordinary Weather-glaes: as will be much more manifet, if it be for a while et neer the fire, o as to be a little warmed by it. Now the humors and juices of our bodies, have likewie the • r certain proportion of air in them, and that in a far greater meaure, than common water, which eems of all other liquors to contain the leat (as is probable from the mall inclination it has to be fermented) and therefore it eems to follow, that upon all changes in the Air, or Medium, the juices of our bodies are affected: (even after the ame manner, as has been aid of common water) and that according to the alterations of the Weather, of day and night, and of the eaons of the year. Which alterations, or changes, in any one particular
place, have a kind of orderly method of ucceeding one another, but much different from that of another place or Region, which, though it have the like alterations of Weather, Seaons, &c. yet the order or method of this variety, is as it were, of another Scale from that of the former. And the differences of heat and cold, denity and rarity in the Medium, are either greater or maller, than thoe of the former: whereby the body removed from the place of its former aboad, to another, is affected with the varieties aforeaid, after another manner than what was uual to it. Whereby the face (if I may o ay) or complexion of the humors and juices in the body, will be much altered and changed from what it lately was: and conequently, the Morboe Character very much defaced, if not wholly obliterated. Which effect will in all probability more certainly ucceed upon often, than upon once changeing the air, as has been already ufficiently evinced, both from reaon and experience.

5. Of all changes of the air, that is commonly oberved to be mot effectual, for
the cure of any ditemper gotten abroad; which is made by removal from a forreign Country, to a mans own Native Soil, or the place of his birth, and firt abode: which eems to be true (caeteris paribus) from hence, that the Aerious Particles, which originally go, as one principal ingredient to the making up of the body, were at firt of the ame tone exactly with that of the Medium: and it cannot be imagined, but that upon any coniderable removal, thee Aery Particles mut be more or les dilated, or contracted, than they formerly were, whereby the body will be preternaturally affected. Which though during the tate of health, it be not caue ufficient, perhaps, to manifetly hinder any action of the body; yet in cae of a dieae, it eems to be a notable relief to Nature, to be retored again to its Native contitution (as far as is poible) which is a kind of renewing, and no mall refrehment to the body: from whence a Patient eldome fails of a relief, and very often finds a perfect cure, in everal contumacious dieaes.

6. I would not be o far miundertood:
as if I aerted the alterations our bodies uffer from the Medium, to be exactly the ame, in degree, with thoe of the Weather-glas; for that I think were hardly conitent with perfect health, as we find thee alterations in mot perons are: though in infirm bodies they are very manifet. But I uppoe, by this time, it may be expected from me, that I give an account of this difference, and ay how it comes to pas, that the air in our bodies is not affected by the Medium exactly, after the manner of the Weather-glas, but in a les degree, where for the only reaon I can think of, I hall aign the tone or tonical motion of every body o often mentioned; which being compreive of all the parts of our bodies, it very coniderably checks and hinders that dilation of the humors, by means of the rarified air, which would otherwie enue upon the like affection of the Medium: which compreion, or reitance of the tone, or tonical motion of the body, may be very well illutrated from a bottle full of (nothing but) air, well topt, and afterward expoed to the differences of heat and cold. In which cae, it
cannot be imagined, that the included air, is at all either dilated, or contracted: not the firt, becaue there is no room for it to expand it elf upon, nor yet the lat, becaue the ides of the Bottle are not apt to ubide, without which, no ufficient reaon can be given, why the air, upon external cold, hould quit any part of the place it formerly replenihed. And yet in ome caes, the differences of heat and cold may be o great, as to prevail over the trength of an ordinary bottle, and break it, as has been often found by experience. But here we mut oberve, that though the ides of the bottle give no way at all to the air included, yet the tonical power of the body doth omewhat yield to uch alterations of the humors; and that more or les, according to its different trength in the body, of this or that individual. Nor doth this experiment of the Bottle ufficiently conclude, but that, at leat, the compreion of the air in our bodies, ought to anwer that of the Medium: and indeed, that it doth not, eems to proceed from the internal heat in the humors of Animals, (maintained, as is aid in the Chapter of
Sanguification) which is of power ufficient, not only to reit the compreion of the tone, or tonical motion of the habit of the body, but that of the medium alo. And hould the contrary happen, death would inevitably enue.

7. It may be farther noted, that all bodies (whether men, or other Animals) are not equally affected with the ame change or alteration in the Medium; but, as hath been aid, proportionably to the trength of the tonical power of each body. And thus it happens, that a peron of a Robut Contitution, and habit of body, (whether uch naturally, or acquired by much travel and labour) will with les trouble and hazard of his health, endure any notable alteration, or change of Weather or Soil, than another of a finer Texture and compoure; and whoe tone conequently is not o reitive of the impreions from without, as that of the former. And thus it is eaie to conceive, why a peron inhabiting neer either of the Poles of the Earth, and removed to, or neer the Equator: or the contrariwie, will find the temper of that Clime more troubleome
and offenive to his health, than he hall, that from the middle temperate Region, hall transfer himelf to either of the extremes. And no doubt, the les the difference is, the eaier and ooner hall a mans Nature be brought to comply with it. And thus we oberve, that Spaniards and Portugezes, do with les danger, travel and trade into the more Southern Regions of the world, than Northern men can do, who are commonly not otherwie eaoned, than by ome dangerous Calenture, Flux or Spam, or other deplorable dieae, whereby much, the greater part of them, are commonly detroyed. All which dieaes are no other, than the effects the Medium hath upon the Air imprioned in our bodies; which if it finds the humors eaily dipoed to a farther degree of fermentation, than what is conitent with health, it produces a Fever or Calenture in ome bodies; in others, a dangerous Flux: and in ome mot violent Spames, upon the forcible dilatation either of the Air in the nervous parts, or of that, which may poibly be, in the paces between the Mucles.

8. From hence probably it is, that
the fruits of thoe hotter Countryes are o dangerous, epecially to trangers; for that they are no ooner received into the body, but they are traightways very violently fermented (and after the ame manner ferment the juices of the body, to the diordering of the whole frame) in o much, that the juice of ome plants, is accounted a deadly poyon, as that of the Root of Yucca (while the olider parts are made into a kind of wholeome bread) and poibly, for no other venomous quality, than its over-active fermentation, whereby it not only diturbs, but detroys the Oeconomy of the body. All which, and much more of this kind, that might be produced, eems in great part to depend upon the finenes, or rarity of the Medium, which lying lighter on liquors, and other bodies thus fermented, uffers them more eaily, and more violently, to expand themelves, than, for the mot part, is uitable with the health of uch as eat them, epecially in any coniderable quantity.

9. And now from what hath hitherto been aid, it may eem exceeding probable, that the Air doth coniderably alter, and
dipoe the humors of our bodies, epecially upon changing one Clime for another; and that our bodies do, more or les, ympathize with the preent tone and temper of the Medium; whereby it is not only freed from everal ditempers, but may alo very often be thereby variouly diaffected, and cat into divers dangerous dieaes. But yet, how ueful oever the changing of the Air may be, for the cure of any infirmity: we find it tands with the convenience but of very few, to make uch removals; for that they cannot well dipene, with the leaving their Families or Relations, together with other their familiar affairs, or imployments. Beides, Phyitians are not apt to advie their Patients to it, till they have firt, in vain, imployed mot other remedies in the cure of them; whereby commonly the oportunity is lot, and the ick peron deprived of that benefit he might, in all probability, have received, upon a more eaonable removal. Beides, many times, it would be neceary, not only to remove to ome neighbouring place, or other, but even to take a journey of ome hundreds of miles, which cannot be performed
by the ick, but with great difficulty. So that what through one impediment, or other, the thing happens to be but rarely put in practie; and o Noble a Remedy, is not only neglected, but in a manner brought into dieteem with ome, for want of more frequent examples of the great ue of it; while they cannot give themelves a atisfactory account, how uch a change of the Air hould o coniderably work upon our bodies.

10. Now to the end we may not want the help of o generous a remedy; and for the better avoiding the fore-mentioned inconveniences in the ue of it. I hold it a matter of no mall compendium, in this place, briefly to et down, and hew the manner of a certain contrivance, how any peron may receive the benefit he may expect, upon removal from his abode, to any other place (with intent to change the air) and that almot indifferently at any eaon of the year, without o much as removing out of his own houe, or neglecting any occaions whatoever. Firt therefore, in ome fit place neer, or adjoyning to your houe, erect a convenient Room, of about
ome twelve or fourteen foot quare, or of what ize you pleae, either bigger or maller than the former, and let it be exactly well cieled, or vaulted over head, and well paved; or otherwie o floared at bottom, that the air may not have any vent, to get either out, or in, nor yet through the walls, which it is requiite hould be of brick or tone, and well plaiter'd on the inide; and let the windows be likewie o contrived, that no air may pas in or out that way, which the eaier to prevent, and that they may be alo the tronger, and les apt to crack, they ought not to be very big, nor many. The door mut be likewie o contrived, that it may hut into its frame o exactly, that when it is made fat, there may not be the leat paage left for the air to get in or out of the foreaid Chamber. The particular manner and contrivance of doing all which, I do not here et down, for that I doubt not, but there are ingenious Maons and Joyners, that will much exceed any directions, that I can be able to give them. Your Air-Chamber being thus made, you mut farther provide your elf with a very large pair of Organ Bellows, which
mut be placed in ome convenient part of the Room, where by the help of a Skrew, the Noe of them may be exactly joyned to a Copper Pipe, whoe other end mut pas through the wall of the Room, and have a value, opening outward, exactly fitted to it, as is uual in Water Engines: and if the aid Value be placed in water, it will do much better. This Brazen Pipe mut likewie have another Value to open inward, and both o contrived, that either of them may be et open at any time, or taken off, while the other is imployed. The Bellows being thus fitted, and the door and windows cloe hut, you may at pleaure either fill the Chamber with Air, by forceing in what quantity you pleae, till there be twice or thrice as much as there was at firt, ti • l the ame be as thick as is requiite. You may likewie dicharge the Chamber of one third, one half, or more of the air it had at firt in it, till you have on the contrary, brought what remains, to that degree of Tenuity (or thinnes) is required, and this by the help of the Bellows; which if the air be to be forced out, mut lie with their moveable part upwards; and
the innermot Value of the Brazen Pipe, before mentioned, mut either be taken off, or kept contantly open: but if air is to be forced into the Chamber, then the Bellows will need to be turned the wrong ide upward; and the outward Value of the Bras Pipe mut be taken off, or kept open, and the innermot Value uffered alone to play. In which caes, working gently with the Bellows, you may either charge, or dicharge (as I may ay) the Air-Chamber at your pleaure, and conequently, obtain an Air in it, of what rarity or denity you pleae. The meaure of which variety, that you may the more exactly take an account of (and that there may be very little or no mitake in the ue of this Chamber) it will be abolutely neceary, to have contantly with you, a large Weather-glas: And you may likewie have a Tub of glas, of ome forty inches long, filled with Quick-ilver, and inverted into a little Earthen or Wooden Veel, half filled, with a quantity of the ame material, after the manner of the Torricellian experiment; and thee are to erve you for Regiters: for by the acent,
and decent of the Water, in the Weather-glas, will be noted to you, by the degrees, on the neck of the Glas, in what prop • rtion you have either rarified or condened the Air within the Room: and you may by help of it, rectifie the tone of the Air, to what degree is requiite, or injoyned. The ue of the Quick ilver Tub, is the very ame, but will not give o exact an account, of every mall difference, as the former, by reaon of the mall quantity of Air contained in it: but yet will not want its ue in other experiments, not relating to Phyick, which I hall not here touch upon, as too remote from what we here handle. Such therefore, as imploy this contrivance, only in Relation to their Health, may content themelves with a Weather-glas, which will prove much an exacter Regiter, than the Quick-ilver Tub, as hath been already hewed.

11. As to the particular application of the ue of the newly decribed Domicilium, or Air-Chamber, 'twill not be amis to repeat, what we before aerted in the precedent Chapter; namely, that as health it elf, is maintained by a due and uitable
fermentation of the humors in our bodies, and that within a certain latitude. So, if the irregularity of the aid motion, or fermentation, be great enough, to become the caue of the manifet abolition, or weakening only, of any action of our bodies, the party o affected, is aid to be ick, or dieaed: and as all dieaes may be divided into acute, whereto are thoe of hort continuance to be referred (though they are not uually termed Acute, taking the word more trictly) and Chronical affections: or ele (which comes to the ame thing) they may properly enough be divided into dieaes, participating of heat, or of cold. The former of which we have already defined, to depend upon uch an irregular fermentation of the blood, and Mas of humors, wherein the ame are more violently moved, than is conitent with health: of which kind are all continual and intermittent Fevers, all Inflammations, mot Fluxes, and everal other ditempers: and contrariwie, all Chronical, or cold affections, eem to depend upon uch an irregularity of the foreaid Fermentation, whereby the humors are not o ufficiently
moved, and agitated, as is requiite to health; of which kind are the Scurvey, the Rickets, all Dropies, ome Fluxes, mot affections of the Spleen, and probably the Gout, and other Arthritical ditempers. Now the method of uing this Domicil, or Air-Chamber, in general, will be this, that where the dieae eems to depend upon a deficient Fermentation of the humors, in uch cae, the Patient (being put into the aid Chamber, and the door cloe hut) hall, by degrees, dicharge the ame, or force the air out; till having coniderably alter'd the tone, and rarified what remains, he till finds himelf to breath freely, or at leat with no great difficulty; at what time he may oberve, how low the water is decended in his Regiter, or Weather-glas, which will hew him how far he may afely, at another time, dicharge the air, without danger of Cramping; which ues to enue, if the air be too exceedingly rarified. On the other ide, if the dieae be Acute, and eem to depend upon the too violent Fermentation of the humors, then it is neceary the Chamber be well charged with air, to what degree
of Toleration hall eem convenient. And here we are principally to provide, that no difficulty of breathing enue, which oftner happens in this practie of condened, than attenuated air. Now the term of the Patients continuance in the Chamber, at one time, is to be defined in Chronical dieaes, as well from his own occaions, as other circumtances; and generally two, three, or more hours, may eem ufficient, and that epecially in the morning, when the ue of other Remedies are found mot conducible. But in acute dieaes, it hould eem neceary, that the Patient continued in the aid Chamber, during the whole coure of the dieae, and that the tone of the air be prudently altered, after the directions of ome able Phyitians, according as the times of the dieae hall eem to require; epecially in intermittent Fevers, where the time of the whole Paroxime mut be pent in the Chamber, and the cold fit requires to be treated as a cold dieae, with rarifying the air, as the hot fit, by condening it, which mut be carefully oberved. Now though there may be many dieaes, as the Stone, the French Pox, and ome other,
which do not depend o immediately, upon the aforeaid irregularities of the Fermentation of the humors; yet I hould not doubt, even in thee, to commend the ue of this Domicil, or Air-Chamber: for that while Nature is thereby much trengthened in all her Natural Functions, it mut needs follow, that he will from hence, at leat, be enabled the better to endure the conflict with thoe dieaes, if, at lat, he do not wholly get the better of them. It will farther be neceary here to add, that in maligne dieaes, and where we require an amendment of the inenible tranpiration; we are, as in cold dieaes, to rarifie, and not condene the air in the Domicil, where the Indication is rather preervative, than curative, as Phyitians ue to peak.

12. To ay omething of the ue of this contrivance, in time of health, we hall only propoe it, as a good expedient to help digetion, and epecially inenible tranpiration, and facilitate breathing and expectoration; and conequently, as of excellent ue, for prevention of mot affections of the lungs, where they are feared; and that generally, what ever the benefits of
changing the air, are, may be reaonably expected from the ue of this Domicil; and that after a more certain regular way, than without it, for that by the means of it, a peron may erve himelf with uch air, as were not otherwie to be found, but on the top of the Pike of Teneriff, or ome other very high Mountain: nay, if it were convenient, as perhaps it may in ome very contumacious affections, he may rarifie the air to a far higher degree, and make it uch, as is not again to be found upon the face of the whole inhabitable world. But as well in icknes, as in health, thoe great excees are not to be ventured upon, but by degrees. The ue of this Domicil may be farther extended, for preventing the inconvenience which may enue, upon any great change of air, by travelling into forreign Countryes; whereby a peron may at pleaure reduce the tone of the air, to that of his own Soil or Climate: and probably, if the ame might be made ue of aboard Ships, it would (with the additional contrivance of a Chair, or Bed, hung after the manner of a Sea-Compas) prevent that
very trouble affection whereto freh men are o ubject, called Sea-icknes; and conequently, become very erviceable to uch, whoe imployments ingage them to undertake Voyages into very remote parts, and there to reide, far from their own Countryes. There may, I doubt not, everal other coniderable concluions be performed, by means of this contrivance: As alo, that the thing it elf is very capable of good improvement, as to the projection of it, far beyond that decribed by us. All which, together with what hath been already aid, and undertaken by us, on the behalf of it. We leave for farther dicovery, and confirmation, to practie and experience.

13. Among the improvements which this contrivance of an Air-chamber is probably capable of, it is in my judgement none of the leat that may be obtained, by joyning the practie of S. Sanctorius, in his Medicina Statica, to this of ours. For as the promotion of the tranpiration by the habit of the body (than which, nothing conduces more to the preervation of health, and prevention of dieaes) is one of the mot
coniderable among thoe many benefits we promie our elves by it: So, if we hall have, as Sanctorius directs, a Statera Romana, in our Air-chamber, it will be of very great conequence, for acertaining the Methodical ue of it, whereby it will become les ubject to gues or hazard. For as the Weather-glas, before-mentioned, will dicover to us, the degrees of rarity and denity, introduced in the incloed air: So the Balance, will with the ame exactnes inform us, at what rate this Diaphoretical tranpiration, is either improved or abated: and at the ame time give us the true weight (in Ounces and Drachmes) of thoe inenible Effluvia, which continually pas that way. For the Patient, weighing himelf (for intance) firt at even of the clock in the morning, and again at nine or ten (having firt exonerated himelf) and abtaining from meat and drink, in the mean time; hall thereby perceive how much (by weight) of his aliment, or rather of the unprofitable part thereof, in thoe two or three hours, paed inenibly through the pores of his body. Let him again repeat the ame experiment, the day following,
with the ame circumtances, in the Air-chamber: and he will not be a little urprized, to find half o much more, and perhaps, twice the quantity evacuated, after the ame inenible manner (or è contra) and that in uch proportion, as he hall have uffered more, or les, of the included air, to have paed into the circumtant Medium, (or è contra) of what proportion the Weather-glas, as a faithful Regiter, hall give him a very particular account. I will not farther inlarge, upon this additional practie, of the Scale or Balance: much les add any thing of the ue of inenible Tranpiration, leat I might offend uch, as are better vered in Statical Experiments; by the unprofitable repetition, of what they are already o well acquainted with: or by giving an ill account of a book I have but once read over, and that neer twenty years ince, deprive others of that olid benefit they may receive, by perual of the above-commended Treatie of Sanctorius.

14. As this contrivance of the air-chamber, is bet fitted for the improvement of health, and the abolihing uch Morboe Characters,
as depend upon the over-low, or too nimble fermentation of the Humors. So it were eaie to project, great Veels, after the manner of Cupping-glaes, ome capable to receive the whole Thighs, others fitted for the Arms: whereby we may at pleaure, (as the eat of ome particular dieaes hall direct) make uch powerful revulions, as hall not only be ufficient, to charm, as it were, and dipoe of uch humors, as Phyitians call Turgid, and Motu Peccantes: but even dicharge particular parts of uch humors, as have eated themelves there already; and may, beides that of Cupping-glaes, very fitly upply the place of the tronget Ligatures. Which practie, as it may be very available, in mot affections of the head: In inflammations, or other tumors or charges, of particular parts: So (not having yet had ufficient opportunity to confirm this my Opinion, by the frequent ue of it) I hall content my elf at preent with having done little more, than named it only.

15. I hall add farther, that the ue of this Air-chamber, may in ome caes, but after a weaker and more uncertain manner,
be upplied by a long-etting Swing, which is found to be a very agreeable exercie, by mot people that have ued it: if their bodies have not been very impure, or firt duly prepared. And by it many perons, affected with Chronical ditempers, taking their original from a deficient fermentation, have found benefit. For, motion conducing o much (as has been aid) to the exciting of all fermentation, (which is viible in Syrups, and other juices of Vegetables haken, and as a proof of it, that Brandee Wine, is accounted the bet, that upon haking bubbles and works mot) no wonder if the eaonable continuance of this moderate, reciprocal motion of the Swing, do by degrees, (though not o uddenly as in the fore-mentioned intances of Syrups, &c. becaue the humors in our bodies lie not o looely as they, in Veels of glas or tone) produce the ame effect, we oberve without, in other liquors. Nor is the fermentation (or call it concoction) of the humors in their Veels, hereby only advanced: But likewie the ditribution of the firt, and econd ways, (if I may o call them) is very much promoted: For
till, as the body is carried forward, o of ten are the Abdominal Mucles, gently and equally compreed, whereby the chyle is the more nimbly pretended from the Intetines forward, to mingle with blood. And again, upon the reces of the body, the Abdomen being les compreed, than if the body et till in the ame cituation, is more dilated than uually, and conequently receives the chyle flowing, more plentifully from the tomack into the Intetines. So that, if it come fater into the guts, and be driven fater out, it mut of neceity follow, that the ditribution thereof hall be more readily performed. Now, for what we lately called, the ditribution of the econd ways, that eems by the ue of the Swing, to be improved after this manner: while the body moves forward, as the foreparts are more compreed by the Medium, o the back parts are les compreed (and thereby, as we may ay, their tone weakened) whereby the habit doth not o forcibly reit the afflux of humors flowing to that part: as in its middle, natural, and quiet cituation. And thus reciprocally, firt one part, and then the other, are omewhat better
dipoed, for the Reception of their alimentary juices, which I call the ditribution of the econd ways. And thus much may uffice to have aid at preent, concerning this matter. I hall only deire my Reader, that he will not be over precipitious, nor let the novelty of our attempt urprize him to a prejudice: and that he be firt, for his own ake, well aured, he is Mater of thoe principles, upon which this Fabrick of ours (as upon o many goodly Pillars) tands erected, before he proceed to condemn us. But if upon the erious perual of this Treatie, by uch whoe Authentick Cenure we mot value and Reverence, we happen to be found light in our own Balance: We have at leat to plead, that we have neither mipent much of our own, or their time in writing, or reading of it. And that though we failed, the deign was great and Honourable, and directed to the benefit of mankind, which may in good part plead our excue, and their good favour make out the ret.
